comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: A Miss Beatrice Williams, 24, of Great Britain, was among the survivors of the Lusitania: www.rmslusitania.info/people/lusitania-survivors/ Mr. George Benjamin Lane, 26, was the only Lane listed among the survivors. www.rmslusitania.info/people/second-cabin/george-lane/ Lane and Williams seem to have been part of a Welsh musical group, the Gwent Royal Welsh Singers, returning to Wales on the Lusitania. Found this about her experience in the sinking: "Preston-Smith was with Beatrice Williams and they ran back downstairs to get lifejackets. Miss Williams was placed in a boat and told to get out again. "The ship was listing so heavily," she said, "that I had to jump. Mr. Preston-Smith jumped with me and I was picked up and put on a raft." www.encyclopedia-titanica.org/lusitania-lest-we-forget-2....

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: I think you are right about G.B. Lane. A detailed account of the actions of the Gwent Choir after the sinking is in the Brooklyn Daily Eagle of May 30, 1915 . I'm not sure Williams was in the choir, but instead escaped with Lane, who was. She isn't mentioned in the account: "Dewi Michael, the director of the singers, was one of those who bound the floating pieces of wreckage and capsized boats together into a makeshift raft, by which many were saved. The other singers who managed to keep near him and help build the raft were G. B. Lane. Risca Williams, Gwyn Jones, Spencer Hill and Preston Smith." www.fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%205/Brooklyn%20NY%20Daily...
